verses.text: Hence those souls must be accounted as passing an exile in Hades, which people are apt to regard as carried off by violence, especially by cruel tortures, such as those of the cross, and the axe, and the sword, and the lion; but we do not account those to be violent deaths which justice awards, that avenger of violence.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 56:20
verses.text: So then, you will say, it is all the wicked souls that are banished in Hades.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 56:21
verses.text: (Not quite so fast, is my answer.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 56:22
verses.text: ) I must compel you to determine (what you mean by Hades), which of its two regions, the region of the good or of the bad.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 56:23
verses.text: If you mean the bad, (all I can say is, that) even now the souls of the wicked deserve to be consigned to those abodes; if you mean the good why should you judge to be unworthy of such a resting-place the souls of infants and of virgins, and those which, by reason of their condition in life were pure and innocent?.

chapters.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:1
verses.text: It is either a very fine thing to be detained in these infernal regions with the Aori, or souls which were prematurely hurried away; or else a very bad thing indeed to be there associated with the Biaeothanati, who suffered violent deaths.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:2
verses.text: I may be permitted to use the actual words and terms with which magic rings again, that inventor of all these odd opinions—with its Ostanes, and Typhon, and Dardanus, and Damigeron, and Nectabis, and Berenice.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:3
verses.text: There is a well-known popular bit of writing, which undertakes to summon up from the abode of Hades the souls which have actually slept out their full age, and had passed away by an honourable death, and had even been buried with full rites and proper ceremony.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:4
verses.text: What after this shall we say about magic? Say, to be sure, what almost everybody says of it—that it is an imposture.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:5
verses.text: But it is not we Christians only whose notice this system of imposture does not escape.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:6
verses.text: We, it is true, have discovered these spirits of evil, not, to be sure, by a complicity with them, but by a certain knowledge which is hostile to them; nor is it by any procedure which is attractive to them, but by a power which subjugates them that we handle (their wretched system)—that manifold pest of the mind of man, that artificer of all error, that destroyer of our salvation and our soul at one swoop.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:7
verses.text: In this way, even by magic, which is indeed only a second idolatry, wherein they pretend that after death they become demons, just as they were supposed in the first and literal idolatry to become gods (and why not? since the gods are but dead things), the before-mentioned Aori Biaeothanati are actually invoked,—and not unfairly, if one grounds his faith on this principle, that it is clearly credible for those souls to be beyond all others addicted to violence and wrong, which with violence and wrong have been hurried away by a cruel and premature death and which would have a keen appetite for reprisals.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:8
verses.text: Under cover, however, of these souls, demons operate, especially such as used to dwell in them when they were in life, and who had driven them, in fact, to the fate which had at last carried them off.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:9
verses.text: For, as we have already suggested, there is hardly a human being who is unattended by a demon; and it is well known to many, that premature and violent deaths, which men ascribe to accidents, are in fact brought about by demons.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:10
verses.text: This imposture of the evil spirit lying concealed in the persons of the dead, we are able, if I mistake not, to prove by actual facts, when in cases of exorcism (the evil spirit) affirms himself sometimes to be one of the relatives of the person possessed by him, sometimes a gladiator or a bestiarius, and sometimes even a god; always making it one of his chief cares to extinguish the very truth which we are proclaiming, that men may not readily believe that all souls remove to Hades, and that they may overthrow faith in the resurrection and the judgment.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:11
verses.text: And yet for all that, the demon, after trying to circumvent the bystanders, is vanquished by the pressure of divine grace, and sorely against his will confesses all the truth.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:12
verses.text: So also in that other kind of magic, which is supposed to bring up from Hades the souls now resting there, and to exhibit them to public view, there is no other expedient of imposture ever resorted to which operates more powerfully.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:13
verses.text: Of course, why a phantom becomes visible, is because a body is also attached to it; and it is no difficult matter to delude the external vision of a man whose mental eye it is so easy to blind.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:14
verses.text: The serpents which emerged from the magicians' rods, certainly appeared to Pharaoh and to the Egyptians as bodily substances.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:15
verses.text: It is true that the verity of Moses swallowed up their lying deceit.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:16
verses.text: Many attempts were also wrought against the apostles by the sorcerers Simon and Elymas, but the blindness which struck (them) was no enchanter's trick.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:17
verses.text: What novelty is there in the effort of an unclean spirit to counterfeit the truth?  At this very time, even, the heretical dupes of this same Simon (Magus) are so much elated by the extravagant pretensions of their art, that they undertake to bring up from Hades the souls of the prophets themselves.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:18
verses.text: And I suppose that they can do so under cover of a lying wonder.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:19
verses.text: For, indeed, it was no less than this that was anciently permitted to the Pythonic (or ventriloquistic) spirit—even to represent the soul of Samuel, when Saul consulted the dead, after (losing the living) God.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:20
verses.text: God forbid, however, that we should suppose that the soul of any saint, much less of a prophet, can be dragged out of (its resting-place in Hades) by a demon.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:21
verses.text: We know that "Satan himself is transformed into an angel of light"—much more into a man of light—and that at last he will "show himself to be even God," and will exhibit "great signs and wonders, insomuch that, if it were possible, he shall deceive the very elect".

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:22
verses.text: He hardly hesitated on the before-mentioned occasion to affirm himself to be a prophet of God, and especially to Saul, in whom he was then actually dwelling.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:23
verses.text: You must not imagine that he who produced the phantom was one, and he who consulted it was another; but that it was one and the same spirit, both in the sorceress and in the apostate (king), which easily pretended an apparition of that which it had already prepared them to believe as real—(even the spirit) through whose evil influence Saul's heart was fixed where his treasure was, and where certainly God was not.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:24
verses.text: Therefore it came about, that he saw him through whose aid he believed that he was going to see, because he believed him through whose help he saw.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:25
verses.text: But we are met with the objection, that in visions of the night dead persons are not unfrequently seen, and that for a set purpose.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:26
verses.text: For instance, the Nasamones consult private oracles by frequent and lengthened visits to the sepulchres of their relatives, as one may find in Heraclides, or Nymphodorus, or Herodotus; and the Celts, for the same purpose, stay away all night at the tombs of their brave chieftains, as Nicander affirms.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:27
verses.text: Well, we admit apparitions of dead persons in dreams to be not more really true than those of living persons; but we apply the same estimate to all alike—to the dead and to the living, and indeed to all the phenomena which are seen.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:28
verses.text: Now things are not true because they appear to be so, but because they are fully proved to be so.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:29
verses.text: The truth of dreams is declared from the realization, not the aspect.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:30
verses.text: Moreover, the fact that Hades is not in any case opened for (the escape of) any soul, has been firmly established by the Lord in the person of Abraham, in His representation of the poor man at rest and the rich man in torment.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:31
verses.text: No one, (he said,) could possibly be despatched from those abodes to report to us how matters went in the nether regions,—a purpose which, (if any could be,) might have been allowable on such an occasion, to persuade a belief in Moses and the prophets.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:32
verses.text: The power of God has, no doubt, sometimes recalled men's souls to their bodies, as a proof of His own transcendent rights; but there must never be, because of this fact, any agreement supposed to be possible between the divine faith and the arrogant pretensions of sorcerers, and the imposture of dreams, and the licence of poets.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 57:33
verses.text: But yet in all cases of a true resurrection, when the power of God recalls souls to their bodies, either by the agency of prophets, or of Christ, or of apostles, a complete presumption is afforded us, by the solid, palpable, and ascertained reality (of the revived body), that its true form must be such as to compel one's belief of the fraudulence of every incorporeal apparition of dead persons.

chapters.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:1
verses.text: All souls, therefore, are shut up within Hades: do you admit this? (It is true, whether) you say yes or no: moreover, there are already experienced there punishments and consolations; and there you have a poor man and a rich.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:2
verses.text: And now, having postponed some stray questions for this part of my work, I will notice them in this suitable place, and then come to a close.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:3
verses.text: Why, then, cannot you suppose that the soul undergoes punishment and consolation in Hades in the interval, while it awaits its alternative of judgment, in a certain anticipation either of gloom or of glory?  You reply: Because in the judgment of God its matter ought to be sure and safe, nor should there be any inkling beforehand of the award of His sentence; and also because (the soul) ought to be covered first by its vestment of the restored flesh, which, as the partner of its actions, should be also a sharer in its recompense.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:4
verses.text: What, then, is to take place in that interval? Shall we sleep? But souls do not sleep even when men are alive: it is indeed the business of bodies to sleep, to which also belongs death itself, no less than its mirror and counterfeit sleep.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:5
verses.text: Or will you have it, that nothing is there done whither the whole human race is attracted, and whither all man's expectation is postponed for safe keeping? Do you think this state is a foretaste of judgment, or its actual commencement? a premature encroachment on it, or the first course in its full ministration? Now really, would it not be the highest possible injustice, even in Hades, if all were to be still well with the guilty even there, and not well with the righteous even yet? What, would you have hope be still more confused after death? would you have it mock us still more with uncertain expectation? or shall it now become a review of past life, and an arranging of judgment, with the inevitable feeling of a trembling fear? But, again, must the soul always tarry for the body, in order to experience sorrow or joy? Is it not sufficient, even of itself, to suffer both one and the other of these sensations? How often, without any pain to the body, is the soul alone tortured by ill-temper, and anger, and fatigue, and very often unconsciously, even to itself? How often, too, on the other hand, amidst bodily suffering, does the soul seek out for itself some furtive joy, and withdraw for the moment from the body's importunate society? I am mistaken if the soul is not in the habit, indeed, solitary and alone, of rejoicing and glorifying over the very tortures of the body.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:6
verses.text: Look for instance, at the soul of Mutius Scaevola as he melts his right hand over the fire; look also at Zeno's, as the torments of Dionysius pass over it.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:7
verses.text: The bites of wild beasts are a glory to young heroes, as on Cyrus were the scars of the bear.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:8
verses.text: Full well, then, does the soul even in Hades know how to joy and to sorrow even without the body; since when in the flesh it feels pain when it likes, though the body is unhurt; and when it likes it feels joy though the body is in pain.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:9
verses.text: Now if such sensations occur at its will during life, how much rather may they not happen after death by the judicial appointment of God! Moreover, the soul executes not all its operations with the ministration of the flesh; for the judgment of God pursues even simple cogitations and the merest volitions.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:10
verses.text: "Whosoever looketh on a woman to lust after her, hath committed adultery with her already in his heart".

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:11
verses.text: Therefore, even for this cause it is most fitting that the soul, without at all waiting for the flesh, should be punished for what it has done without the partnership of the flesh.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:12
verses.text: So, on the same principle, in return for the pious and kindly thoughts in which it shared not the help of the flesh, shall it without the flesh receive its consolation.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:13
verses.text: Nay more, even in matters done through the flesh the soul is the first to conceive them, the first to arrange them, the first to authorize them, the first to precipitate them into acts.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:14
verses.text: And even if it is sometimes unwilling to act, it is still the first to treat the object which it means to effect by help of the body.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:15
verses.text: In no case, indeed, can an accomplished fact be prior to the mental conception thereof.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:16
verses.text: It is therefore quite in keeping with this order of things, that that part of our nature should be the first to have the recompense and reward to which they are due on account of its priority.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:17
verses.text: In short, inasmuch as we understand "the prison" pointed out in the Gospel to be Hades, and as we also interpret "the uttermost farthing" to mean the very smallest offence which has to be recompensed there before the resurrection, no one will hesitate to believe that the soul undergoes in Hades some compensatory discipline, without prejudice to the full process of the resurrection, when the recompense will be administered through the flesh besides.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:18
verses.text: This point the Paraclete has also pressed home on our attention in most frequent admonitions, whenever any of us has admitted the force of His words from a knowledge of His promised spiritual disclosures.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:19
verses.text: And now at last having, as I believe, encountered every human opinion concerning the soul, and tried its character by the teaching of (our holy faith,) we have satisfied the curiosity which is simply a reasonable and necessary one.

verses.name: Tertullian: a Treatise on the Soul 58:20
verses.text: As for that which is extravagant and idle, there will evermore be as great a defect in its information, as there has been exaggeration and self-will in its researches.
